Royal_Wade_Kimes:
{{short description|American country music singer (born 1951)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Royal Wade Kimes | image = | image_size = | landscape = | caption = | birth_name = Royal Wade Kimes | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1951 |3|3}}{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=225|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}} | birth_place = [[Chester, Arkansas]], U.S. | origin = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S. | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter | instrument = Vocals | years_active = 1996–present | label = [[Asylum Records|Asylum]], Wonderment | associated_acts = }} '''Royal Wade Kimes''' (born March 3, 1951) is an American [[country music]] singer. ==Biography== Kimes was the last cowboy to ride the Ark/Ok. border country, running cattle on the open range. He and his father ran a sawmill until he moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 1983. He also worked at [[Loretta Lynn]]'s [[dude ranch]] and later began recording demos through the encouragement of [[Eddy Arnold]]. Kimes also wrote the cut "We Bury the Hatchet" on [[Garth Brooks]]' album ''[[Ropin' the Wind]]'', and signed with [[Asylum Records]] in 1996. The label released the single "Leave My Mama Out Of This",{{cite magazine|last=Price|first=Deborah Evans|date=September 28, 1996|title=Sky's the Limit for Royal Kimes|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|pages=33, 35|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vwkEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22Royal+wade+kimes%22&pg=PA33}} followed by his debut album ''Another Man's Sky''.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/royal-wade-kimes-mn0000353347|title=Royal Wade Kimes}} Following Leave My Mama Out Of This was the album's title track, which was made into a music video.{{cite magazine|date=June 14, 1997|title=Production notes|magazine=Billboard|page=84|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2w8EAAAAMBAJ&q=%22royal+wade+kimes%22+%22another+man%27s+sky%22&pg=PA84}} The album's third single, "Guardian Angel", received a positive review in ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', which called it "country to the core" and praised Kimes as a "talented songwriter".{{cite magazine|date=June 28, 1997|title=Single reviews: Country|magazine=Billboard|page=75|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fQ8EAAAAMBAJ&q=%22royal+wade+kimes%22+%22asylum%22&pg=PA75}} After Kimes left Asylum, he began recording for Wonderment Records. Kimes charted at number 60 on the [[Hot Country Songs]] chart dated January 3, 2004 with "Mile High Honey". Following the song Mile High Honey Kimes began having hits abroad on Hot Disc Top 40/1st release On The Border topped the chart at no.1 followed by Ride at no.1 His song Cut The Line top out at no 2 and more followed. ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:16em;"| Title ! style="width:18em;"| Album details |- ! scope="row"| ''Another Man's Sky'' | * Release date: 1996 * Label: [[Asylum Records]] |- ! scope="row"| ''A Dyin' Breed'' | * Release date: 2002 * Label: Wonderment Records |- ! scope="row"| ''Cowboy Cool'' | * Release date: 2004 * Label: Wonderment Records |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row"| ''Snow'' | * Release date: 2005 * Label: Wonderment Records |- | * Release Date: 2000 * Label: Wonderment Records |- ! scope="row"| ''Hangin' Around the Moon'' | * Release date: 2005 * Label: Wonderment Records |- ! scope="row"| ''Strikin' Matches'' | * Release date: 2006 * Label: Wonderment Records |- ! scope="row"| ''How the West Was Sung'' | * Release date: 2008 * Label: Wonderment Records |- ! scope="row"| ''White Light'' | * Release date: 2009 * Label: Wonderment Records |- ! scope="row"| ''Crossing the Roads'' | * Release date: 2011 * Label: Wonderment Records |- ! scope="row"| ''A Proud Land'' | * Release date: 2012 * Label: Wonderment Records * Release Date: 2015 * Label: Wonderment Records |- !
